paper_citation: Da'ar, O. B., & Kalmey, F. (2023). The level of countries' preparedness to health risks during Covid-19 and pre-pandemic: the differential response to health systems building blocks and socioeconomic indicators. Health Economics Review, 13(16)
regions_compared: Yes, compares preparedness across WHO regions and income levels
geographic_factors: Geographic location (WHO regions), resource availability (supply chain capacity)
institutional_factors: Governance effectiveness, health financing systems, policy compliance with international norms, socioeconomic development level (SDGs, HDI)
infrastructural_factors: Supply chain capacity for medicines and technologies, communication infrastructure, health workforce (doctors and nurses per 1000 population), hospital beds per 1000 population
other_resilience_factors: Social development goals (SDGs), Human Development Index (HDI), income level
evidence_strength: Medium, uses comprehensive GHS index data but relies on macro-level indicators that may not reflect actual pandemic response capabilities
resilience_phase: Varying levels of health system building blocks and socioeconomic indicators across regions
implemented_measures: Strengthening supply chain capacity, health financing, communication infrastructure, and governance effectiveness
proposed_measures: Supply chain capacity, governance effectiveness, health financing, and communication infrastructure were the main factors enhancing regional resilience to pandemic risks
main_resilience_factors: Yes, effects of health system building blocks were considerably larger for countries with higher levels of preparedness
differential_effectiveness: Yes, high-income countries showed complacency in preparedness despite better resources
resilience_tradeoffs: African region was identified as least prepared; Southeast Asia, Europe, Americas, and West Pacific regions were more prepared than Africa
resilience_type: \The results show that increases in effective governance
key_quotes: supply chain capacity in terms of medicines and technologies
additional_notes: and financing had positive effects on countries' level of preparedness to health risks. These effects were considerably larger for countries with higher levels of preparedness to health risks.\" \"The negative trend in the level of preparedness to health risks would suggest that there is a need for better preparedness during pandemics by conflating national health with global health risks.\""
